data.text:
In the 690's there was a propaganda war between the Islamic Caliphate and the Byzantine Empire.

The Caliphate minted coins inscribed with "There is no God but God alone; Muhammad is his messenger."

The Byzantine's responded by minting coins with the Emperor on one side and an image of Jesus on the other.

The Caliphate responded by issuing this coin.

It is said to either depict Abd-al Malik, (the Caliph) or Muhammad.

If it is Muhammad then it is the first known image of him and was drawn when there were still people alive who knew what he looked like.

Supposedly Muhammad's surviving followers who knew him were uncomfortable with his image being used on a coin as it may have violated Islam's policy of no religious images.

The coins were only in circulation for a short period of time before they were replaced with coins sporting lines from the Quran.

So is the image Muhammad or Abd-al Malik???

It could be that the image is Muhammad but was said to be Abd-al Malik to prevent the coins from being deemed heretical.

Well for one, it wasn't Jesus that was on the Byzantine coin, but rather the sign of the cross. The corresponding side on the Islamic coin had a pillar with a globe on top. No idea, but I will suggest it's meant to represent Mohammed in a metaphysical sense because putting an actual image of him on the coin is considered heresy.

But it -did- happen. Around 70 years after Mohammed's death, in the 690's, the Caliph produced an extremely rare coin said to have his image on it. We think this is so because this issue was recalled and all the coins were destroyed, except for the very few that survived like this one.

On the left, Mohammed is said to be the figure in the middle, flanked by the Caliph and his wife. It's not only the earliest image of him, but most likely the only one ever issued on a coin.

So the figure on the coin in the OP above is most likely the Caliph himself and the writing probably includes his name (Abd al-Malik).

It is my understanding the Islamic ban is against any image of a person or animal, not just Mohamed. So an Islamic coin could not bear an image of the caliph either. To avoid violating the ban on graven images, Islamic visual art is usually based on plants or geometric patterns.

You don't have to go very far to find figural Islamic art, though. Qusayr 'Amra is a major early example, and Iran produced plenty of it as well. Still, I have no problem saying that Islamic art is less iconic than most traditions of Christian art.
